Award.AwardTitle: Impact of Assimilating Satellite Microwave Radiance on Tropical Cyclone Rapid Intensification Forecasting
Award.AbstractNarration:
Significant and steady progress has been made in understanding and predicting tropical cyclone (TC) motion over the past 15-20 years. In contrast, only modest improvements in intensity prediction have been made over the same period. The primary objective of this study is to improve understanding and prediction of intensity change of tropical cyclones by assimilating satellite microwave observations into atmospheric prediction models. Unlike visible and infrared channel observations, microwave satellite data convey especially rich information originated from deep in the cloud/precipitation layers, therefore, reflect the distributions of hydrometeors within TCs. This makes microwave observations particularly advantageous in overcast and rainy TC areas.

Many meteorological satellites that are currently in operation carry sensors operating at microwave frequencies. Passive radiance observations at frequencies lower than 80 GHz are more sensitive to cloud liquid and raindrops, while those at higher frequencies are more sensitive to cloud ice, snowflake, and graupel. In this project, we investigate how these satellite microwave observations can effectively be assimilated into hurricane forecasting models (WRF and MM5) to provide improve analyses of cloud ice, snow, cloud liquid, and raindrop distributions within TCs, which may, in turn, pose a positive impact on hurricane intensity forecasts.

Intellectual merits. New and effective ways of applying these hydrometeor-sensitive data to TC analysis and forecast at different resolutions will be developed. In particular, we will: (i) develop and refine forward observation operators of microwave radiances through model verification with observations; (ii) design and test an effective quality control algorithm for these data; (iii) incorporate the new observation operators and the satellite microwave data into a hurricane data assimilation system; and (iv) assess the role of accurate analysis of ice, snow, liquid water, and raindrops in TC rapid intensification forecasts.

Broader impacts. The research activity will impose a significant scientific, technological, and societal impact. Improvement of forecasts of hurricane intensity and convective processes are important and challenging. The assessment of the impact of the satellite hydrometeor data on these forecasts and the development of new techniques to use these data will advance the science of hurricane research and prediction. The work will also provide benefit to the society by minimizing damages caused by hurricanes. The research activity will train two graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this project, we investigated how satellite microwave observations can be effectively assimilated into numberical weather prediction models to improve models' ability to forecast tropical cyclones' intensification. The research can be largely divided into three major components, i.e., development of improved forward radiative transfer model for microwave radiance data assimilation, development of better methods for satellite data quality control, and improvement of tropical cyclone forecasts by assimilating microwave radiance data from multiple  satellite platforms. 

In forward radiative transfer model development, a special single-scattering database has been generated to handle the scattering properties by nonspherical ice particles and snowflakes. This scattering database is a major step forward in handling ice scattering compared to traditionally used "sphere" approximations. It has implemented by several currently available radiative transfer models, such as CRTM and RTTOV. 

For satellite data quality control, a method has been developed for more efficiently use of total ozone data from AIRS retrievals in the vicinity of hurricanes, which significantly increased the utility of AIRS data in assimilations - reducing the unuseable data from 20%-30% to 5%-10%. Additionally, methods have been developed to remove angle-dependent noise and noise strips in Microwave Humidity Sounder (MWHS) sensors. The noise removal improved the quality of satellite data to be assimilated into numerical weather prediction models.

Quality controlled satellite radiance data are then assilimated into the Hurricane Weather Research and Forecasting (HWRF) system. First, by implementing a better cloud detection algorithm, quantitative precipitation forecasts have been improved when assimilating Microwave Humidity Sounder data. Second, by studying 4 hurricane landfall cases, it is found that Advanced Technology Microwave Sounder data assimilation results in a consistently positive impact on the track and intensity forecast of the 4 landfall hurricanes. Additionally, a case study of assimilating GOES imager radiance data has carried out for hurricane Debby (2012). It is found that the largest positive impact on the track and intensity forcasts comes from a combined effect of radiance data assimilation and an asymmetric vortex initialization.

    In this research, we have developed the methodology of assimilating information-rich satellite microwave data into numerical weather forecast models. It advanced our fundamental understanding on the intensification of tropical cyclones. The data assimilation and data analysis methods developed under this project are transferable to other science disciplines such as oceanography, hydrology, and so on.

The following journal articles have been resulted from this project:

Wang,H., X.Zou, G.Li, 2012: An improved quality control for AIRS total ozone observations within and around hurricanes. J. Atmos. Ocean. Tech., 29, 417, doi: 10.1175/JTECH-D-11-00108.1.
